description: Comprehensive extraction of all Bluebook rules regarding numerals, symbols, numbers, ordinals, ranges, section symbols, and formatting conventions

primary_rule.title: Numerals and Symbols
primary_rule.content: In text, spell out numbers zero through ninety-nine, and any number that begins a sentence. Use numerals for 100 and above. In citations, use numerals for all numbers (e.g., "115 F.3d 123"). Use symbols (like § and ¶) as appropriate in citations, but in text, use words ("section" or "paragraph") unless referring to a specific section symbol as a symbol.

rules: Spell out numbers zero through ninety-nine
Spell out any number that begins a sentence
Use words like 'section' or 'paragraph' instead of symbols
Use numerals for all numbers (e.g., '115 F.3d 123')
Do not spell out numbers in citations

rule_3_3.title: Sections and Paragraphs
rule_3_3.content: Many legal documents, statutes, and regulations are divided into sections (§) or paragraphs (¶). When citing such subdivisions, use the appropriate symbol followed by the number (without a period). If citing multiple sequential sections, use a double section symbol ("§§"). For nonconsecutive sections, separate by commas.

format_rules: Use § followed by number without a period

rule_12_1.title: Basic Citation Forms for Statutes
rule_12_1.content: The basic form for statutes: [Official Name of Act], [published source] [section symbol and number] ([year]). If the act is commonly known by a name, use that name.

details.section_usage: Always include section symbol (§) with statute citations

rule_12_2.title: Choosing the Proper Citation Form
rule_12_2.content: Use the official code if available (e.g., U.S.C. for federal statutes). If a statute is spread across multiple code sections, cite as a range (e.g., 42 U.S.C. §§ 9601-9675). If the statute is not in the code yet, cite the session law. If an unofficial code is more up-to-date or commonly used in practice, you may use it in court documents (with an indication of currency or year). In law review, typically stick to official codes whenever possible.

key_points: Use range format for multiple sections
Use double section symbol (§§) for ranges

examples: There are five elements to the claim.
The statute applies to 115 different violations.

special_cases.rule: Always spell out, regardless of number

notes: All numbers in citations use numerals regardless of magnitude
This applies to case citations, statute citations, page numbers, etc.

section_symbol.name: Section symbol
usage: Cite constitutional provisions: U.S. Const. art. III, § 2
rules: Use § followed by number without period
Do NOT use 'section' or 'sec.' when § is used

paragraph_symbol.name: Paragraph symbol
usage: Used in court documents and practice materials

notes: Do NOT use hyphens (-) for ranges
En-dash is the proper typographic mark

sequential_numbering.rule: For multiple sequential items, use double symbol

format_rules: Spell out in formal text if appropriate
monetary_amounts.note: While not explicitly detailed in Bluebook Rule 6.2, monetary amounts follow standard number formatting rules

format_options: In citations and formal contexts: use numeral with %
percentages.note: While not explicitly detailed in Bluebook Rule 6.2, percentages follow standard number formatting rules

formatting: In text (below 100): spell out ordinals (first, second, third...)
In text (100+): use numerals with ordinal suffix (101st, 225th)
In citations: use ordinals as needed (12th Circuit, 5th Amendment)

rule_7.title: Italicization for Style and in Unique Circumstances
rule_7.content: Words may be italicized in text for emphasis or stylistic purposes, but use this sparingly. In legal writing, certain terms are traditionally italicized: words used as words, foreign words not commonly used in English, and letters or numerals referenced as such.
italicize_numerals_when: Referring to letters or numerals as themselves (e.g., 'the numeral 5', 'the letter a')
Discussing the form or appearance of the number/symbol
Using as a word itself: 'The 's' in statutes is important'

rule_6_1.title: Abbreviations
rule_6_1.content: Use standard abbreviations for case names (table T6), institutional author names (T7), periodical titles (T10), publishing terms (T8), and geographical terms (T10). Do not abbreviate words in textual sentences (except widely known acronyms), but always abbreviate as shown in tables when in citations.

years.full_dates: Use when decision date is essential

spacing.rule: Use nonbreaking space between symbol and numeral
spacing.technical_note: Use Option+Space on Mac; Ctrl+Shift+Space on PC

metadata.note: This comprehensive extraction consolidates Rule 6.2 (Numerals and Symbols) as the primary rule with related rules and formatting conventions for numbers, symbols, and ranges
